text:
This piece was originally published on January 31, 2025. New content is regularly added.

With the declaration of a national emergency at the U.S. southern border and the classification of migration as “an invasion,” U.S. President Donald Trump made his focus on immigration clear on the first day of his second term, taking action on an issue that was a focal point in his 2024 presidential campaign. Since then, immigration enforcement authorities have received a significant budget boost as they make record numbers of arrests and pursue the president’s goal of 1 million deportations in 2025.

No doubt, Trump’s migration policy over the course of his term will touch upon Latin America. Just over half of the U.S. foreign-born population comes from the region, per 2023 census data—almost 24.5 million people. According to statistics from Pew Research Center, Latin Americans also make up around 74 percent of an estimated 14 million immigrants lacking full legal status in the United States. This includes people with temporary protections from deportation, such as a pending asylum claim, Temporary Protected Status (TPS), or humanitarian parole. The Trump White House has already moved to strip these protections from hundreds of thousands of immigrants from the region, many of whom either have been or can be deported even while these measures make their way through the courts.

During his first term (2017–2021), Trump passed policies that pressured Latin American governments to take more responsibility to deter migration and accept deportees. This term, Trump is resurrecting—or intensifying—several of those policies. Trump is also attempting to end birthright citizenship by reinterpreting the 14th Amendment and threatening a wider set of countries with punitive measures if they don’t comply with his requests around deportation.

AS/COA Online is monitoring Trump's government approach to migration. Learn about his most recent initiatives and how the policies of his second presidency are different from the actions he took in his first term.

Trump's Migration Impact in Charts

See recent statistics on the effects of evolving U.S. immigration policy on border crossings, detentions, and deportation flights.

Recent Developments

November 7: Temporary Protected Status ends for 250,000 Venezuelans

About a quarter of a million Venezuelan immigrants in the United States are set to lose TPS on November 7. This follows a Supreme Court ruling on October 3 that allowed the Department of Homeland Security to cut short a Biden-era extension to this program that would have provided Venezuelan recipients protection from deportation until October 2026 (see October 3 entry).

This group of Venezuelan TPS holders join another 350,000 Venezuelans under a distinct TPS designation who lost their legal right to live in the United States immediately following the October 3 Supreme Court decision. They are at risk of deportation, unless they can acquire another immigrant status.

October 31: Trump administration sets record low cap on refugee admissions

In a Presidential Determination published on October 31, the Trump White House limited refugee admissions for fiscal year 2026 to 7,500 people. It is the lowest admissions cap since the U.S. refugee resettlement program began in 1980. The cap for fiscal year 2025, set by the Biden administration, was 125,000.

For much of the program’s history, refugees from Latin American and the Caribbean rarely represented more than 10 percent of overall admissions to the United States. However, the number of refugees from the region grew tenfold between 2022 and 2024, an increase largely driven by Venezuelan displacement. In 2024, a record 25,348 Latin American and Caribbean citizens made up around one-quarter of refugees resettled in the United States. Venezuelans represented around half of refugees from the region in 2024, with Guatemalans and Nicaraguans being the second- and third-largest Latin American refugee populations resettled in the United States last year.

The Presidential Determination states that Afrikaners from South Africa will be given priority in admissions, as well as “other victims of illegal or unjust discrimination in their respective homelands.”

October 3: Supreme Court allows Trump administration to strip Temporary Protected Status for Venezuelans

Ruling in favor of an emergency appeal from the Trump administration, a 6-3 Supreme Court majority allowed the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to end TPS for Venezuelans. The temporary order from the Supreme Court overrules a previous judgement by a lower court in San Francisco, which had reinstated this protection from deportation until October 2026 and ruled that the DHS did not have the authority to bring an early end to TPS designations (see September 5 entry).

The emergency ruling means that around 350,000 Venezuelans are at immediate risk of deportation. Another TPS designation held by an additional 250,000 Venezuelans is due to expire in November.

September 5: Federal court restores Temporary Protected Status for Haitians and Venezuelans

U.S. District Judge Edward Chen of San Francisco on September 5 ruled against the Trump administration’s early termination of TPS for Haitians and Venezuelans. The ruling restores the rights to live and work in the United States to around 350,000 Venezuelans whose TPS designation expired in April and safeguards this protection from deportation for another 250,000 whose status was due to expire on September 10. It also reaffirms a July order from a federal judge in New York that determined it was unlawful to cut TPS short for the more than 520,000 Haitian immigrants who either possess TPS or are eligible for it.

Chen’s 69-page opinion stated that the DHS decisions to cancel TPS extensions granted by the Biden administration were unprecedented and hasty, and that DHS Secretary Kristi Noem had exceeded her authority in doing so. A DHS response the order argued that “the TPS program has been abused, exploited, and politicized as a de facto amnesty program.” The Trump administration is expected to appeal the ruling.

In January 2025, shortly before leaving office, the Biden administration extended two TPS designations for Venezuelans until October 2026. Protections for Haitians had previously been extended to February 2026, but Noem’s DHS attempted to bring forward the expiration date to August 2025. Subject to appeal, the 2026 expiration dates for both nationalities remain in place.

September 2: Federal appeals court rules against use of Alien Enemies Act to speed deportations of Venezuelans

In a 2–1 majority decision on September 2, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit determined that the Trump administration cannot use the Alien Enemies Act (AEA) to expedite the deportation of Venezuelan immigrants it alleges are members of the Tren de Aragua cartel. The ruling sided with arguments from lower courts and immigration advocates that the eighteenth-century wartime act was not intended to remove alleged gang members.

The 185-page ruling stated that “mass immigration” could not be equated to “sending an armed, organized force to occupy, to disrupt or to otherwise harm the United States,” and that there was “no invasion or predatory incursion” as defined in the AEA. The legal case is likely to return to the Supreme Court for a final ruling.

Earlier this year, in March, the Trump administration invoked the AEA to deport 137 Venezuelans to a megaprison in El Salvador. U.S. government allegations that these deportees belong to Tren de Aragua have been refuted in various investigations. Most of those imprisoned in El Salvador were returned to Venezuela in a July prisoner swap (see July 18 entry).

August 31: Judge blocks repatriation of Guatemalan migrant children

On August 31, a U.S. District Court judge in Washington, DC stopped the repatriation of Guatemalan children who had arrived unaccompanied to the United States. In her emergency ruling, issued while dozens of minors were aboard flights set to depart from Texas, Judge Sparkle Sooknanan ordered that the children could not be removed without a deportation order and that they must remain in the country for at least two weeks as legal challenges to their removal play out. Hundreds of unaccompanied Guatemalan migrant children under the custody of the U.S. government are said to be targets for removal, according to sources cited in a CNN report.

Representatives of the Trump administration claimed the children’s parents had requested their return. In a statement released on August 31, the Guatemalan government said that it is undertaking “coordinated actions” with the United States to reunite unaccompanied minors with their families in Guatemala, an agreement that came out of Homeland Secretary Kristi Noem’s trip to Central America in June. The press release added that these actions should be conducted “according to established protocols.”

August 29: Federal appeals court rules that expedited end of Temporary Protected Status for Venezuelans is unlawful

A three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit on August 29 came to the unanimous decision that the Trump administration does not have the power to cut short Temporary Protected Status (TPS) designations for Venezuelan immigrants. In their opinion, the judges wrote that “no administration has attempted to vacate an existing temporary protection status designation in the 35 years in which the program has existed.” The decision reaffirmed a March ruling by a lower court in San Francisco, but it is unclear how it affects the Supreme Court order issued in May that allows the government to deport Venezuelans who already lost TPS protections due to earlier actions by the government (see previous entries).

The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) announced in February the reversal of a Biden-era measure that extended TPS for some 600,000 Venezuelans until October 2026. Around 350,000 Venezuelans registered under a 2023 TPS designation began losing their protection from deportation in April and another 250,000 registered under a 2021 designation are set to lose their status in September.

August 20: Federal court allows termination of Temporary Protected Status for Hondurans and Nicaraguans

The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeal for the Ninth Circuit voted on August 20 to permit the Trump administration to end TPS for tens of thousands of Honduran and Nicaraguan immigrants. The ruling is a response to an appeal from the administration to suspend a July 31 decision from U.S. District Judge Trina Thompson in California that had paused the government’s effort to withdraw this legal protection from deportation. Thompson had postponed the termination of TPS for these nationalities until at least November, when a hearing to determine the legality of the government’s action is scheduled to take place.

The Central American TPS holders are set to lose this legal status in September, in accordance with a pair of DHS notices published on July 8 (see July 7 entry). According to U.S. government data, there are around 72,000 Hondurans and 4,000 Nicaraguans residing in the country with TPS. Of these, approximately 21,000 Hondurans and 1,100 Nicaraguans are also green card holders. Those without another legal status will lose access to work permits and become eligible for deportation.

Thompson’s ruling stated that the DHS did not conduct an “objective review of the country conditions” before ending deportation protections and that certain statements from DHS Secretary Kristi Noem “may demonstrate discriminatory intent” toward immigrants. In a rebuttal, the DHS released a statement reiterating its stance that Honduras and Nicaragua are “safe for their nationals to return home.”

July 18: Venezuelan deportees released from El Salvador in exchange for U.S. nationals detained in Venezuela

The governments of El Salvador, the United States, and Venezuela announced on July 18 that around 250 Venezuelans were repatriated from El Salvador’s maximum-security Terrorism Confinement Center, or CECOT, in exchange for the return of 10 U.S. nationals jailed in Venezuela. Also included in the three-country deal was the release of about 80 Venezuelan political prisoners from domestic jails.

Many of those returned to Venezuela were immigrant detainees that the U.S. government deported to El Salvador in March under an eighteenth-century wartime law called the Alien Enemies Act (AEA). It was reported at that time that Salvadoran President Nayib Bukele had agreed with the Trump administration to hold up to 300 third-country deportees in CECOT for a year for a fee of $6 million. A U.S. federal judge subsequently ruled the use of AEA illegal, barring further deportations under this law. However, that decision is subject to an ongoing appeals process.

The five U.S. citizens and five U.S. residents freed from Venezuelan prison were arrested on suspicion of plotting against the Maduro regime, according to Venezuelan authorities. Arrests took place between August 2024 and January 2025.

July 7: Hondurans and Nicaraguans will lose Temporary Protected Status after more than 25 years

In a pair of press releases issued on July 7, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) announced that Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for Hondurans and Nicaraguans will come to an end in September 2025. According to DHS notices set to be published on July 8, around 72,000 Hondurans and 4,000 Nicaraguans have TPS, protecting them from deportation and providing a legal right to live and work in the United States. Those without another legal status will be vulnerable to deportation in two months' time.

The U.S. government first designated TPS for these two countries in 1999, following the destruction wrought by Hurricane Mitch, a category 5 hurricane that remains one of the deadliest Atlantic storms on record. Successive administrations—both Republican and Democrat—continually extended the designation. During the first Trump administration (2017–2021), DHS attempts to terminate TPS for Hondurans and Nicaraguans were held up by legal challenges and then reversed by the Biden administration (2021–2025).

In the press releases, DHS Secretary Kristi Noem stated that these countries have displayed sufficient recovery from the damages of Hurricane Mitch and that conditions were safe for their respective citizens to return home. Both countries are currently under a level 3 travel advisory—the second-highest level issued by the State Department—which warn potential travelers of the risk of crime and, in the case of Nicaragua, the threat of “arbitrary enforcement of laws, the risk of wrongful detention, and limited healthcare availability.”

July 1: Judge blocks early termination of Temporary Protected Status for Haitians

U.S. District Judge Brian Cogan on July 1 ruled that the decision of the DHS to bring an early end to TPS for Haitians was unlawful. In his ruling, Cogan stated that the government had failed to provide sufficient notice to TPS holders and that DHS Secretary Kristi Noem "cannot reconsider Haiti's TPS designation in a way that takes effect before February 3, 2026, the expiration of the most recent previous extension."

Just days prior, in a statement released on June 27, the DHS announced that Haitian immigrants would no longer have TPS from September 2. Over 521,000 Haitians who either have or are eligible for this legal status in the United States would have been subject to deportation if they did not apply or were ineligible for other forms of legal stay.

According to that release, Secretary Noem “in consultation with the Department of State […] determined that, overall, country conditions have improved to the point where Haitians can return home in safety.” A current State Department travel advisory, however, highlights risks of “kidnapping, crime, [and] civil unrest” in Haiti. Recent UN reports note that up to 90 percent of Port-au-Prince is controlled by armed gangs and that violence is spreading to other parts of the country, while almost 1.3 million people face internal displacement amid record levels of malnutrition.

The attempted termination followed an effort earlier this year by the DHS to rollback a Biden-era extension to TPS for Haitians. A February notice had brought the expiration date forward to August 2025 from February 2026 (see prior entries).

June 9: Travel restrictions come into effect for 19 countries, including Cuba, Haiti, and Venezuela

Starting on June 9, the U.S. government will bar Haitian nationals from entering the United States as well as deny entry to Cubans and Venezuelans seeking to travel on common types of business, tourist, student, and academic visas. The restrictions do not apply to persons with a valid visa that was issued before June 9.

President Trump issued a proclamation on June 4 restricting the entry of citizens from a total of 19 countries. Of those, 12, including Haiti, are subject to an almost complete ban on travel and the issuance of any type of visa. The other seven, including Cuba and Venezuela, will not have access to many types of visitor and immigrant visas. However, the proclamation also instructs consular offices to limit the length of stay permitted on other types of non-immigrant visas, such as employment visas.

The Trump administration cited rates of overstay and perceived threats to national security as the reasons for restricting travel and immigration from citizens of these countries. In the case of Haiti, the administration noted that the country “lacks a central authority” able to properly screen potential travellers and immigrants to the United States, representing a national security risk. The U.S. embassy in Port-au-Prince has not processed visa requests for at least two years, according to the Miami Herald.

Likewise, the U.S. government stated that Venezuela lacks a “competent or cooperative authority” responsible for issuing travel documents and citeds difficulties in coordinating deportation arrangements. Despite a few disruptions, there have been regular deportation flights from the United States to Venezuela during the second Trump administration.

The proclamation used similar justifications for including Cuba, adding that it is a “state sponsor of terrorism.” The U.S. embassy in Havana has not issued visitor visas since 2017, resulting in Cubans often traveling to third countries to apply for these visas.

Exceptions to the restrictions for the 19 countries include green card holders, travelers with diplomatic and other types of official visas, certain categories of family reunification visas, and dual nationals who have a passport from a country not included on the list. The Departments of State and Homeland Security will review the list of countries after the first 90 days, then every six months.

June 6: Kilmar Abrego García returned from El Salvador to face charges in the United States

Kilmar Abrego García, a Salvadoran-born man who was deported from the United States to El Salvador’s CECOT prison in March alongside 260 other immigrants, was returned to the United States on June 6 to face criminal charges. He has been accused of two counts related to transporting undocumented migrants “for financial gain.”

Abrego García’s case has attracted attention from top U.S. politicians and international media, particularly after the White House admitted he was mistakenly deported. His deportation resulted in a legal back-and-forth between the Trump administration and federal courts about bringing him back to the country (see prior entries).

May 30: Supreme Court clears the way for deportation of Cuban, Haitian, Nicaraguan, and Venezuelan humanitarian parolees

In an emergency order issued on May 30, the Supreme Court overrode a lower-court decision that had suspended the Trump administration’s truncation of humanitarian parole protections for Cubans, Haitians, Nicaraguans, and Venezuelans. This leaves parolees who have not acquired another legal status subject to deportation. Over 530,000 individuals benefited from this two-year protection since it was introduced by the Biden administration—first for Venezuelans in October 2022 and then expanded to the other three nationalities in January 2023, when it became known as the CHNV program.

The Supreme Court order was a response to the government’s emergency appeal of an April 14 ruling issued by Judge Indira Talwani of Massachusetts. Less than two weeks before a Department of Homeland Security (DHS) order ending the CHNV program was due to come into effect, Talwani ruled that early termination of a legal status given to noncitizens should not be carried out en masse, but on a case-by-case basis. In its appeal, the Department of Justice argued that this would place an undue administrative burden on the government and added that the DHS had the right to make these decisions without influence from the judiciary.

The Supreme Court ruling is not a final determination on the legality of the March DHS order that sought to bring the program to an end in April. However, CHNV parolees can still be deported while a lawsuit challenging the DHS order proceeds in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit in Boston.

April 30: Federal judge orders that migrant detainees at Guantánamo be given notice before third-country deportation

U.S. District Judge Brian Murphy in Boston issued an order on April 30 instructing the U.S. government to give immigrant detainees being held at the Guantánamo Naval Base in Cuba an opportunity to flag concerns about safety risks if deported to a country other than their own. The order followed the Trump administration’s March 30 deportation of four Venezuelan men—three of whom it alleged were Tren de Aragua members—from Guantánamo to El Salvador’s CECOT prison, despite an order Murphy issued on March 28 restricting expedited third-country deportations.

The Department of Justice had argued in an April 28 hearing that the removal did not violate the judge’s March order because it was conducted by the Department of Defense (DoD) and not the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the agency which Murphy cited in his order. Judge Murphy raised questions about the DoD’s authority to conduct deportations without input from DHS, the agency charged with carrying out immigration enforcement actions.

April 29: President Sheinbaum announces that Mexico has received almost 39,000 deportees since start of second Trump term

During her daily morning press conference on April 29, Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum informed that her country had received 38,757 deportees from the United States since President Trump’s return to office on January 20. Sheinbaum added that 33,311 were Mexican nationals and the rest were non-Mexicans the country had accepted for “humanitarian reasons,” although she did not specify their nationalities. She noted that Mexico had not signed any agreement with the United States to act as a “safe third country,” a deal the U.S. government pushed for during the first Trump presidency.

This represents a drop in deportations to Mexico compared to a similar period last year under President Joe Biden. According to government figures cited by Reuters, the Biden administration deported around 52,000 persons to Mexico from February through March of 2024.

April 20: U.S. government informs that Abrego García is out of El Salvador’s CECOT prison

The State Department informed a federal judge on April 20 that a Salvadoran immigrant deported from the United States has been taken out of El Salvador’s high-security mega-prison, known by its Spanish acronym CECOT. In a filing submitted to a district judge in Maryland, the State Department said that Kilmar Abrego García had been transferred out of a CECOT cell a week prior to “a room of his own with a bed and furniture” in the “administrative building” of another detention facility in El Salvador.

Abrego García has become a high-profile case amid the ongoing legal battle between the judicial system and the Trump administration over his deportation. Abrego García—who had been living in the United States since 2011 and in 2019 received protection from deportation—was deported to El Salvador in March alongside 260 other immigrants the U.S. government claimed to be gang members. On April 10, the Supreme Court ruled that the government should make every effort to bring him back to the United States, but both the U.S. and Salvadoran administrations have said they are unable to do so. On the back of the Supreme Court order, District Judge Paula Xinis of Maryland requested that the government provide daily updates of Abrego García’s condition and whereabouts, and that it document what steps it had taken to facilitate his return. News of Abrego García being moved from CECOT came after Senator Chris Van Hollen (D-MD) visited El Salvador from April 16 to 18 to petition for the Salvadoran’s return to the United States.

Media reports have indicated that many of those deported alongside Abrego García do not have criminal records in the United States. The majority of those removed to CECOT in March were Venezuelan nationals, prompting Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro to call for their release while chiding President Nayib Bukele's "complicity." On April 20, Bukele posted an open letter to Maduro on social media platform X offering a “humanitarian deal” to repatriate the 252 Venezuelan detainees in CECOT to Venezuela in exchange for the release of 252 political prisoners from Venezuela’s jails. In response, Venezuelan Attorney General Tarek William Saab called the proposal “cynical” and asked the Salvadoran governnment to identify each detainee and provide proof of life and medical records.

April 19: Supreme Court blocks use of Alien Enemies Act to deport Venezuelan migrants detained in Texas

In an emergency ruling issued just before 1 a.m. on April 19, the U.S. Supreme Court paused the deportation of a group of Venezuelan immigrants until a lower court had time to decide on the matter. The Trump administration alleges that the Venezuelan immigrants currently detained in Texas are members of Tren de Aragua and had intended to deport the men under the Alien Enemies Act, an eighteenth-century law that had previously only been invoked during active wars.

Lawyers from the American Civil Liberties Union, who filed appeals on behalf of the immigrants, said that the detainees had not been given opportunity to challenge their removal orders before a judge. A Supreme Court ruling earlier in April, which did not prohibit the use of the Alien Enemies Act for expedited deportations, did however affirm that immigrant detainees should be given sufficient time to appeal a deportation order.

The U.S. Solicitor General D. John Sauer has requested the Court’s clarification on whether the Venezuelans detained in Texas could be removed using legal procedures other than the Alien Enemies Act.

April 14: Federal judge stops termination of CHNV parole program

U.S. District Judge Indira Talwani of Massachusetts ruled on April 14 that the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) cannot shutter the humanitarian parole program that has granted over 530,000 Cubans, Haitians, Venezuelans, and Nicaraguans temporary permission to live and work in the United States. The program, which has been available for these four nationalities since January 2023, was set to end on April 24 in accordance with a 30-day notice published on March 25 by DHS. Parolees whose two-year authorization had not yet expired would have lost their legal status and protection from deportation.

In her order, Judge Talwani wrote that the early termination of a legal status conferred on noncitizens should be reviewed on a case-by-case basis. She added in a hearing that DHS had made the decision to end the program with an incorrect understanding of the process, framing parolees as persons who had crossed the border without authorization rather than people who had received permission to enter by air after a vetting process.

April 10: Supreme Court compels return of wrongfully deported Salvadoran migrant

The U.S. Supreme Court on April 10 affirmed a ruling by a district judge that the U.S. government should make all efforts to return Kilmar Abrego García from El Salvador's megaprison. The Trump administration had previously referred to the March 15 deportation of Abrego Garcia alongside 260 other Venezuelan and Salvadoran migrant detainees as an “administrative error.” Abrego García is a Salvadoran who arrived in the United States in 2011 and in 2019 received protection from deportation and permission to work.

The Justice Department (DoJ) argued that the United States has no authority to compel El Salvador to return anyone within its prison system. It also maintained that the U.S. judiciary has no jurisdiction in matters of foreign affairs.

During a visit to the White House on April 14, Salvadoran President Nayib Bukele said he would not return Abrego García to the United States. Responding to a reporter’s question, he said, “I don’t have the power to return him to the United States.” Both Bukele and the Trump administration have claimed that Abrego García is a member of MS-13, a U.S.-based gang with links to El Salvador that the White House recently designated a foreign terrorist organization. Abrego García’s lawyers have denied this claim and argued that the government has not provided evidence to support it.

Which Cartels and Groups Is Trump Designating as Foreign Terrorist Organizations?

The U.S. government named ten criminal groups FTOs—six from Mexico, two from Haiti, and two associated with Venezuela and El Salvador.

April 9: New York and Texas judges block use of Alien Enemies Act in their states

Judges in New York and Texas issued temporary blocks on the use of the Alien Enemies Act to deport immigrants detained within their respective jurisdictions. The orders came despite an earlier Supreme Court ruling that permitted the Trump administration to continue using the eighteenth century wartime act to expedite the deportation of Venezuelan immigrants alleged to be gang members.

On April 7, the Supreme Court ruled against a DC appellate court who had upheld a ban on the deportation of Venezuelan detainees. In a 5-4 decision, the court argued that the case had been filed in the wrong court. However, all nine justices agreed that Venezuelan migrants had to receive advance notice before deportation and sufficient time to challenge the decision before removal.

April 8: Trump administration revokes legal status of CBP One users

The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has informed immigrants who used the CBP One mobile application to gain legal entry into the United States that they no longer have permission to live and work in the country and must leave immediately or risk deportation.

In January 2023, the Biden administration expanded the functions of the CBP One app to allow potential migrants to schedule immigration appointments at authorized ports of entry before crossing the U.S.–Mexico border, as a means of discouraging irregular crossings. Those who obtained appointments were usually given a two-year parole to remain and work while applying for other immigration statuses. More than 935,000 immigrants entered the United States via the app, many of whom are Venezuelan, Cuban, and Mexican, according to a January 14 U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) press release.

On his first day in office, Trump cancelled appointments scheduled through the CBP One app. His administration has encouraged undocumented immigrants to notify authorities of “self-deportation” through the rebranded “CBP Home” app.

April 7: Two Supreme Court rulings affirm deportation actions

Kilmar Armando Abrego García, a Salvadoran migrant who had been living with protected legal status in Maryland, has been the subject of a judicial back-and-forth since his March 15 deportation in what the Trump administration admits was “an administrative error.”

On April 4, U.S. District Judge Paula Xinis of Maryland ordered that Abrego García should be returned to the United States by midnight on April 5, citing his protection from deportation by a 2019 court order. The Trump administration requested a stay for Xinis’ order.

On April 7, the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals denied that request for a stay. Hours later, Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts, acting on behalf of the entire court, issued an administrative order indefinitely lifting the deadline set by Judge Xinis, giving the Trump administration more time to comply with her order. Roberts’ order did not touch on the legal issues in Abrego Garcia’s deportation, though a decision whether the Trump administration acted lawfully is expected in the future. Abrego Garcia remains in El Salvador's "mega-prison."

In a separate ruling that same day, the Supreme Court said that the administration could continue to deport Venezuelan migrants under Trump's invocation of wartime powers granted under the Alien Enemies Act. However, it added that immigrant detainees must receive prior notice and be given the chance to appeal removal.

March 31: U.S. federal judge pauses end of TPS for Venezuelans

Days before around 350,000 Venezuelan immigrants in the United States were set to lose Temporary Protected Status (TPS), a U.S. judge ruled that the February decision by DHS to cancel the extension of this status was unlawful. The judge’s ruling means that, for now, protections for this group of Venezuelan TPS beneficiaries—as well as another 250,000 Venezuelan TPS holders whose status was set to expire in September—will extend to October 2026. This was the date set in an extension order issued on January 17 under the Biden administration (2021-2025). Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem had attempted to reverse that order.

The Trump administration had one week to appeal the judge’s decision.

March 25: DHS terminates humanitarian parole program for Cubans, Haitians, Nicaraguans, and Venezuelans

In a notice published on March 25, DHS announced the end of a humanitarian parole program that granted temporary legal status to more than 530,000 Cubans, Haitians, Nicaraguans, and Venezuelans over the less than three years it was active. The notice advises parolees without an alternative migration status to leave the United States before April 24—the date the program is due to expire—or risk deportation. President Trump had instructed the secretary of Homeland Security to end all parole programs “contrary to the policies of the United States” in an executive order signed on the first day of his second term.

Under the humanitarian parole program, persons applied for entry into the United States through a U.S.-based financial sponsor and were allowed to live and work for two years. The Biden administration introduced the program for Venezuelans in October 2022 and expanded it in January 2023 to include Cubans, Haitians, and Nicaraguans, after which it became known as the CHNV program. Before departing office, President Joe Biden announced in October 2024 intentions to sunset the CHNV program and asked parolees to apply for other immigration statuses for which they may have been eligible, including asylum and temporary protected status. It is unclear how many parolees have already obtained another status.

The March 2025 DHS notice states that parolees who have not applied for an alternative legal status will be targeted for deportation. It also notes that the decision to issue the notice just 30 days in advance serves to facilitate the use of expedited removal procedures—i.e. deportation without a hearing before an immigration judge—which can only be used for immigrants who have spent less than two years in the United States.

March 23: Deportation flights to Venezuela resume

A plane carrying 199 deportees arrived in Venezuela on March 23 on the back of an agreement to resume deportation flights from the United States that was announced the day before. The deportation happened in two stages: An ICE-chartered aircraft flew the Venezuelan nationals to a military base in Honduras, where they were then transferred to a plane operated by Venezuela’s state airline to complete the return journey.

This followed a similar agreement negotiated earlier in March by Richard Grenell, the Trump’s administration envoy for special missions, and came despite the Maduro administration’s rebuke of the expulsion of over 200 Venezuelan immigrant detainees to El Salvador’s mega-prison. Secretary of State Marco Rubio had also threatened on social media platform X to increase sanctions if Venezuela stopped accepting deportees.

In February, Venezuela sent three planes to collect around 370 of its nationals with deportation orders from the United States, some of whom had been detained in the U.S. Naval Base in Guantánamo Bay. This followed a meeting between Grenell and Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro on January 31, during which the two reportedly discussed sanctions, the release of U.S. citizens imprisoned in Venezuela, and the repatriation of undocumented Venezuelan immigrants.

However, on March 4, the Trump administration revoked oil company Chevron’s license to operate in Venezuela, an economic lifeline for the regime. In response, Maduro said that decision “damaged communication” between the administrations and stopped sending planes for Venezuelan deportees.

In November 2022, the administration of then-President Joe Biden granted Chevron special permission to operate in Venezuela as part of negotiations to facilitate “free and fair elections” in the South American country. Despite later reinstating several sanctions on the Maduro regime in April 2024, citing a lack of progress towards a return to democracy, the Biden administration did not suspend Chevron’s license.

March 15: Trump invokes 18th century law to deport hundreds of Venezuelan immigrant detainees to El Salvador

On March 15, the Trump administration deported 261 immigrant detainees—238 Venezuelans and 23 Salvadorans—to El Salvador via Honduras. Some of the deportations were enabled by the president’s invocation of the Alien Enemies Act of 1798, which allows the U.S. government to apprehend, arrest, and deport without an immigration hearing any non-citizen above 14 years of age who comes from a “hostile nation or government."

Although the United States is not formally at war with Venezuela, the Trump administration has claimed that many of the Venezuelan detainees are members of the Tren de Aragua gang, a criminal group the executive order described as “undertaking hostile actions and conducting irregular warfare against the territory of the United States both directly and at the direction, clandestine or otherwise, of the Maduro regime in Venezuela.” Tren de Aragua was designated as a Foreign Terrorist Organization, or FTO, in February by the Trump administration.

Around 135 of the 261 flown out of the United States were deported under the Alien Enemies Act. The White House has yet to provide evidence of the deportees’ membership in the Venezuelan gang.

That same day, a federal judge ordered a 14-day block on deportations under this law in response to lawsuits filed by civil rights organizations. However, two deportation flights were already underway by the time of the ruling. The White House has denied allegations that it defied the judge’s ruling by not ordering the deportation flights to return to the United States before they landed on foreign territory.

Salvadoran President Nayib Bukele—who mocked the judge’s ruling on X—has struck a deal with the Trump administration to imprison 300 suspected Tren de Aragua members in El Salvador’s Terrorism Confinement Center for one year for a fee of $6 million dollars. U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio said on X this would “save [U.S.] taxpayer dollars” and hailed Bukele as “the strongest security leader in out region [and] a great friend of the U.S.”

The Alien Enemies Act had previously only been invoked three times, each during an active war. It was last used during World War II to detain Japanese and German immigrants in the United States.

March 5: United States suspends military deportation flights

In the first week of March, the U.S. government suspended the use of military planes for deportation flights. In an attempt to fulfill his campaign promise of mass deportations, the Trump administration used military aircrafts to perform deportation operations in February in an unprecedented strategy. Military planes were used to transport migrants to Central American countries and to the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba, as well as elsewhere in the world.

However, the strategy encountered various challenges. Countries, including Brazil and Colombia, objected to the use of military planes to return their citizens, while Mexico restricted access to its airspace for these aircrafts. Mexico’s restrictions lengthened flight times for military deportation planes destined for Central and South America, adding to the price of flights that reportedly cost around $28,500 per hour. Civilian flights chartered by ICE cost approximately $17,000 according to former ICE officials cited in The Wall Street Journal.

February 24: Homeland Security rolls back TPS for Haitians

Through a February 24 notice, DHS announced that a Biden-era extension of TPS for Haitian immigrants until February 3, 2026 would instead expire on August 3, 2025. This means that the approximately 521,000 Haitians in the United States who either have or are eligible for TPS are set to lose permission to work and protection from deportation. Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem has until June 4, 2025 to decide whether to re-extend or end this legal status.

Among the justifications cited for the decision to shorten the time frame for these protections, DHS stated that the 2024 deployment of the U.S.-funded and Kenya-staffed Multinational Security Support mission to combat gang violence in Port-au-Prince, Haiti’s capital, represented a “real possibility of an improvement in conditions.” As such, Secretary Noem has committed to reviewing conditions in the country to determine whether it is safe to return Haitians. According to UN estimates, more than 5,600 persons were killed in Haiti in 2024, an increase of over 1,000 from the previous year, with hundreds more wounded and kidnapped. The notice also states that there will be consideration of “whether it is contrary to the U.S. national interest to continue to permit the Haitian nationals to remain temporarily in the United States.”

TPS was first made available to Haitian nationals in 2010 following a powerful earthquake that caused massive destruction in the capital and surrounding areas. Successive governments later extended and added new designations for TPS to protect an increasing number of Haitian immigrants in the United States. In 2018, during Trump’s first term in office, the administration’s attempt to terminate the program was successfully challenged in court.

February 23: New batch of Latin American migrants taken to Guantánamo Bay detention

After deporting the first batch of Venezuelan migrant detainees at the U.S. naval base in Guantánamo Bay, the military resumed flying immigrant detainees to the site on February 23. Among the nationalities taken to the base are Colombians, Ecuadorans, Guatemalans and Salvadorans. Those considered “high-threat” immigrants are reportedly being held in facilities previously used to imprison suspected terrorists.

Back on February 20, the U.S. administration flew 177 of the 178 Venezuelan migrants detained at the base to Honduras, where they were then picked up by a Venezuelan aircraft to complete the journey to their home country. One of the detainees was returned to the mainland United States.

February 17: Rubio’s Central America trip yields deportation deals

In his first trip as secretary of state, Marco Rubio ventured to Central America and the Caribbean with migration as a priority.

On Rubio’s first stop, Panama, President José Raúl Mulino offered the U.S. government use of a landing strip in a town near the Darién Gap as a base for deportation operations. In a press conference on February 2, Mulino suggested that U.S. deportation flights could depart from the Nicanor Air Base to return migrants to their respective countries of origin, including Colombia, Ecuador, and Venezuela, as well as further afield. This builds upon an agreement signed in July 2024 through which the United States finances deportation flights from Panama.

The first of these flights landed near Panama City on February 13 carrying 119 migrants from various Asian countries including Afghanistan, China, and Pakistan. President Mulino explained they would be transferred to a shelter in the Darién province and from there, returned to their home countries. Similar flights to Costa Rica reportedly began on February 17.

Rubio’s following stop was El Salvador, where he announced on February 3 that President Nayib Bukele had offered to take in deportees of any nationality with a criminal record, including alleged gang members, to be held in El Salvador’s mega prison. Bukele later clarified on X that only “convicted criminals” would be admitted “in exchange for a fee.” Both men added that the proposal included the transfer of convicted U.S. citizens, a procedure experts noted would be legally fraught. Rubio referred to the offer as “an act of extraordinary friendship” that would constitute “the most unprecedented and extraordinary migratory agreement anywhere in the world.”

In Guatemala, President Bernardo Arévalo announced in a joint press conference with Secretary Rubio on February 5 that his country would accept 40 percent more deportation flights from the United States and receive non-Guatemalan citizens. Under the Biden administration, approximately 14 flights landed in Guatemala on a weekly basis, with over 66,000 Guatemalans being returned to their country in the 2024 fiscal year.

Tracking Trump and Latin America: Trade—U.S. Senate Votes Against Brazil Tariffs

What does the U.S. president's “America First” trade policy mean for the region? AS/COA is monitoring the new administration's approach.

February 4: Laken Riley Act and Guantánamo migration detention center

The first signed bill of Trump’s second term deals with migration. The Laken Riley Act, signed January 29, stipulates the federal detention of any migrant accused—but not yet convicted—of theft or a violent crime. It also empowers states attorneys general to sue the federal government if they feel there has been harm due to a failure of immigration enforcement.

During that signing, Trump announced that he would direct construction to expand a migrant detention center in Guantánamo Bay. This was later formalized in a memo. The president claimed that the U.S. military site, located in Cuba, could house up to 30,000 migrants, almost doubling the state’s holding capacity for persons under deportation orders. If constructed, it would be the largest U.S. migrant detention center. Flights carrying detained migrants from the mainland United States to Guantánamo began on February 4.

Best known as the site of a detention and alleged torture facility for suspected terrorists, Guantánamo Bay also hosts facilities that have been used intermittently in recent decades to temporarily house migrants and asylum seekers, including under the Biden administration, and to process or return persons picked up at sea.

January 28: Venezuelans to lose protected status

On January 28, the Department of Homeland Security announced the cancellation of an 18-month extension to TPS for Venezuelans. This reversed an order implemented earlier in January by the previous Biden administration that offered over 600,000 Venezuelans with TPS protection from deportation and legal permission to work until October 2026. The reversal means that protections for around 350,000 Venezuelans registered under a 2023 TPS designation will instead expire on April 2, 2025. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem has until July 12, 2025 to make a final determination on whether to extend or end the legal status of Venezuelans registered under a 2021 TPS designation, which is due to expire on September 10, 2025.

Back in 2017, as one of the last acts of his first term, Trump granted Venezuelan migrants protection from deportation for 18 months, using a mechanism similar to TPS.

Following a meeting between Trump’s envoy for special missions, Richard Grenell, and Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro on January 31, Trump stated that Venezuela had agreed to receive deportation flights and offered to provide the means of transportation. Venezuela had stopped allowing the United States to return its citizens in January 2024. The Venezuelan government has not provided details on what was discussed with Grenell, but Maduro stated that they had "taken a first step” towards a new relationship with the United States.

Explainer: Venezuelan Migration Policy in the Americas

Thousands of Venezuelans are expected to emigrate in the wake of July’s election fraud. What legal migration pathways exist in the region?

January 26: Military deportation flights raise regional ire

In his second term, Trump has introduced the use of military aircrafts to carry out deportations, a move experts note is unprecedented in modern history.

Military deportation flights bound for Colombia on January 26 triggered an explosive but short-lived dispute between Trump and Colombian President Gustavo Petro. Early that morning, Petro rescinded flight permissions for two planes carrying Colombian nationals. Petro objected to the use of military vessels and what he considered a lack of “dignified treatment” of those on board.

In response, Trump threatened “decisive retaliatory measures” including: a 25 percent tariff on Colombian goods, to be raised to 50 percent within one week; visa and travel bans for government officials, their families, and “supporters;” and “enhanced” inspections of Colombian nationals at ports of entry. The U.S. embassy in Bogotá also suspended visa processing.

Petro retaliated with the announcement that Colombia would also levy a 25 percent tariff on U.S. goods, along with a missive on X in which he suggested that Trump was plotting a coup, while insisting that he was “not scared of [a] blockade” and that Colombia would “stop looking to the North.” The United States is Colombia’s largest trading partner and purchases around a quarter of all Colombian exports.

However, before the end of the day, both the White House and the Colombian foreign ministry confirmed that deportation flights would resume as normal and that there would be no extra tariffs. The White House added that the tariffs and sanctions would be “held in reserve” should Colombia violate the agreement. Deportation flights resumed on January 28 with Petro sending the Colombian Air Force to carry his citizens to Bogotá.

The diplomatic dispute came just a few hours after the Brazilian government raised similar objections to returning nationals being handcuffed and prevented from using the bathroom on a January 24 deportation flight. When the plane made a stopover in Manaus, President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva sent the Brazilian Air Force to collect the returnees and complete the journey to Belo Horizonte without handcuffs. Brazil’s foreign ministry later sent a diplomatic note to the U.S. requesting clarification on the “degrading treatment” of the migrants.

Also on January 24, Mexico blocked U.S. military planes from passing through Mexican airspace but allowed non-military deportation flights to land domestically. Neither government provided a public explanation for the refusal. In Guatemala, military deportation flights were allowed in on January 25 without issue.

January 20: Early executive orders show immigration priorities

Rhetoric about migration featured prominently in Trump’s inaugural address. He spoke several times about what he deemed “the disastrous invasion of our country” and mentioned specific policies—such as “Remain in Mexico” and large-scale deportation—in his address.

Hours later, Trump signed a series of executive orders that actualized many of the migration promises in his speech. That included declaring a national emergency on the U.S. border with Mexico and categorizing immigration as “an invasion" under the Constitution, which provides legal justification for the federal government to take expanded action on behalf of the states.

Several of Trump’s executive orders marshaled resources to the border for the construction of infrastructure and the use of technology like drones. He also authorized the Department of Defense to send troops to the border. The first wave of the military included 1,500 troops, who began to reach their new posts on January 23.

Trump also modified several immigration policies. This included significantly reducing the geographical and time constraints on expedited removals, a mechanism that facilitates the deportation of undocumented migrants without an immigration hearing. He also resurrected the Migration Protection Protocols (MPP), better known as “Remain in Mexico.” This policy, first implemented by Trump in 2018, forces asylum seekers to wait in Mexico for their U.S. immigration hearings. He suspended the acceptance of refugees under the U.S. Refugee Admissions Program. He ended the humanitarian parole programs for Cubans, Haitians, Nicaraguans, and Venezuelans, leaving over 530,000 people in legal limbo. He also shut down a mobile application that migrants in Mexico used to schedule appointments with U.S. immigration, effectively canceling scheduled proceedings.

2024 Campaign

Immigration formed a central pillar of Trump’s 2024 campaign for reelection. On his campaign website, the first two of 20 “core promises” were to “seal the border and stop the migrant invasion” and “carry out the largest deportation operation in American history.” The Trump campaign insisted that his administration would focus on non-U.S. citizens in the country without legal status. More than three-quarters of an estimated 11 million undocumented migrants in the United States come from Latin America and the Caribbean, according to 2022 data compiled by Pew Research Center.

In the run-up to the election, Trump and his now Vice President JD Vance amplified unverified reports of crimes committed by migrants, including Haitians and Venezuelans, to provide grist for their plans to ramp up persecution and deportation of undocumented migrants. This aligned with another of his “core” campaign promises to “stop the migrant crime epidemic, demolish the foreign drug cartels, crush gang violence, and lock up violent offenders.”

name: Litigation
title: CalFresh rolls out in Monterey County as Trump appeals SNAP ruling to Supreme Court
description:
In Monterey County, residents have begun seeing their full November SNAP/CalFresh benefits on their EBT cards, according to county officials.
Over 51,000 county residents receive CalFresh food assistance, more than half of them children.
"The California Department of Social Services (CDSS) is telling us that California has initiated the distribution of full November CalFresh benefits," county officials stated.
Earlier this week, Monterey County Board of Supervisors approved $150,000 to the Food Bank for Monterey County for additional food support.
About 42 million Americans receive SNAP food assistance.
text:
After a federal court in Rhode Island ordered the Trump administration to release November SNAP funds to the states by Friday, California has started distributing food assistance to CalFresh recipients.

About 5.5. million California residents receive CalFresh, the state's SNAP program.

In Monterey County, residents have begun seeing their full November SNAP/CalFresh benefits on their EBT cards, according to county officials.

Over 51,000 county residents receive CalFresh food assistance, more than half of them children.

"The California Department of Social Services (CDSS) is telling us that California has initiated the distribution of full November CalFresh benefits," county officials stated. "The state took this action in response to the court's ruling in the Rhode Island litigation, which determined that the Trump administration should fully fund the SNAP program for November by today."

On Nov. 6, a federal judge in Rhode Island ordered the Trump Administration to issue full SNAP payments within the day by using contingency funds.

Shortly after the order happened, the Trump Administration issued an appeal.

"Last night, the CDSS indicated that, while this could change, customers who would normally receive their benefits November 1st-7th, are expected to receive their benefits today," the statement continued. "Please note that this may mean some of these customers already have their benefits today, while others may still be in process. Recipients can check their online accounts to find out if their benefits have been received."

County officials warn that because this is an "evolving situation and could change, the CDSS anticipates that customers who would normally receive their benefits Nov. 8-10, are anticipated to have their full benefits available as normal."

Earlier this week, Monterey County Board of Supervisors approved $150,000 to the Food Bank for Monterey County for additional food support.

Trump Administration takes fight over SNAP funding to Supreme Court

After Rhode Island federal Judge John McConnell ordered the administration to make full payments of November SNAP benefits to the states within a day, the Justice Department filed a notice of appeal Nov. 6.

About 42 million Americans receive SNAP food assistance.

On Nov. 7, the DOJ asked the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit to halt McConnell's order by 4 p.m. EDT.

"There is no lawful basis for an order that directs (the U.S. Department of Agriculture) to somehow find $4 billion in the metaphorical couch cushions," the administration said in its request.

The Boston-based 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals declined to intervene.

In response, the Trump administration filed a last-minute appeal on Nov. 7 with the Supreme Court to block the initial court order requiring the government to provide full SNAP food aid benefits.

Katie Wiseman and Sarah D. Wire contributed to this report

text:
A group of moms from the western suburbs were arrested Friday morning during a protest against the separation of families outside of the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in Broadview.

Fourteen mothers jumped over the barricades and sat in a circle on Beach Street to “demand an end” to the immigration raids that have swept through the Chicago area since the Trump administration launched “Operation Midway Blitz” in September.

Less than a minute later, the women were arrested by Cook County sheriff’s deputies. The sheriff’s office confirmed the arrests and said charges were pending.

“We want to encourage other people who feel strongly about ICE’s actions to step off the sidelines and take our cities back,” said Teresa Shattuck, a mother from Oak Park. “We want to use our collective power and our white privilege in the way it should be used.”

Meghan Carter, another mother from Oak Park, said the women who were arrested understood the risks when they chose to take a stand, adding their experiences paled in comparison to what the detained immigrants inside the facility were enduring.

Carter said the suburban moms were a group of parents “fed up” with seeing immigration agents “terrorizing” their communities.

The U.S. Department of Homeland Security did not respond immediately to a request for comment.

About 40 protesters, including the suburban moms, gathered outside the facility Friday morning chanting for an end to the immigration raids.

At the same time, a caravan of about 10 vehicles drove around the facility honking their horns and waving anti-Donald Trump flags. A passenger in one vehicle was seen holding a sign that read, “We are human first.”
